title: Peppa Pig maker Entertainment One explores takeover interest
text:
Tip : Use comma (,) to separate multiple quotes. Learn more... 
Sat, Aug 29, 2015, 22:59 BST - UK Markets closed Peppa Pig maker Entertainment One explores takeover interest By Christopher WIlliams | Telegraph – 2 hours 9 minutes ago 106.20 +2.30 
Film and television company sought interest from with Sky (LSE: BSY.L - news ) and Vivendi (Swiss: VIV.SW - news ) 
Entertainment One (Other OTC: ENTMF - news ) , the film and television company behind Peppa Pig, has been offered for sale to media giants including Sky and Vivendi as its investors seek to capitalise on strong global demand for content rights. 
Advisers to the FTSE 250 company have approached potential bidders in recent months, say City sources. 
But it is understood that Sky was not interested in a making a bid for Entertainment One, partly because the potential target is deeply involved in cinema as well as television and not seen as a good fit for the satellite operator's strategy. 
Vivendi was seen as a better match for Entertainment One, which produces and distributes film and television. 
The French media group makes movies via its StudioCanal unit and owns Canal+ , France’s biggest pay-TV operator. It (Other OTC: ITGL - news ) also recently acquired the YouTube rival Dailymotion , one of several online services that provide a platform for Peppa Pig. 
After selling its telecoms assets in recent years, Vivendi is focused on building up its global scale as a media rights owner and distributor. 
However, it is understood that Vivendi is not currently in discussions with Entertainment One. Sources familiar with the British company said it was not now looking to be acquired. 
Takeover options have been explored as Entertainment One’s biggest shareholder, the investment fund Marwyn, has sought to cash in on the company’s rapid growth. It sold a 9pc stake and gave up its seat on the board in July , sending the shares tumbling. 
Marwyn remains an 18pc shareholder and says it “continues to be excited by the scale of opportunity that faces Entertainment One going forward”. 
Entertainment One has grown rapidly as demand for content rights from pay-TV operators and internet-based on-demand services, such as Amazon and Netflix (Xetra: 552484 - news ) , has ballooned. The firm’s stock market valuation has climbed towards £1bn as it has built a large library of film and television rights through acquisitions, and is now focused on expanding its production arm. 
In a Telegraph interview earlier this year, Darren Throop, Entertainment One’s chief executive, argued the company was nevertheless undervalued by the London market, which has few remaining media stocks. 
All parties declined to comment.
